item.title: Parent Alert! Your Child Just Skipped Class
item.description:
March 2, 2017 - In a study, automated text messages to parents reduced absences and the number of F's earned by high school students.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/ed/2017/03/02/517757199/parent-alert-your-child-just-skipped-class
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 2, 2017 - In a study, automated text messages to parents reduced absences and the number of F's earned by high school students. http://www.npr.org/sections/ed/2017/03/02/517757199/parent-alert-your-child-just-skipped-class

item.title: Someday Disposable Drones May Deliver A Payload, Then Vanish
item.description: March 2, 2017 - DARPA, the Pentagon's R&D agency, is working with partners to develop low-cost gliders that travel about 100 miles and disappear within hours. The vehicles could have humanitarian and military uses.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 2, 2017 - DARPA, the Pentagon's R&D agency, is working with partners to develop low-cost gliders that travel about 100 miles and disappear within hours. The vehicles could have humanitarian and military uses. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/03/02/517043932/someday-disposable-drones-may-deliver-their-load-then-vanish

item.title: Snapchat Parent To Begin Trading On The New York Stock Exchange Thursday
item.description: March 2, 2017 - Snap Inc., the company behind the popular disappearing-message app Snapchat, has priced its initial public offering of 200 million nonvoting shares at $17 each.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 2, 2017 - Snap Inc., the company behind the popular disappearing-message app Snapchat, has priced its initial public offering of 200 million nonvoting shares at $17 each. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/02/518081927/snapchat-parent-to-begin-trading-on-the-new-york-stock-exchange-thursday

item.title: Uber CEO Apologizes Over Video Of Dispute With Driver
item.description: March 1, 2017 - Uber's founder Travis Kalanick says he needs leadership help. The frank acknowledgement comes after video surfaced of him berating an Uber driver, and follows a blistering blog post by a former engineer who said she was subjected to repeated sexual harassment and the company failed to stop it. The question many are asking now is whether Kalanick can continue to serve as the public face of the company he created.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - Uber's founder Travis Kalanick says he needs leadership help. The frank acknowledgement comes after video surfaced of him berating an Uber driver, and follows a blistering blog post by a former engineer who said she was subjected to repeated sexual harassment and the company failed to stop it. The question many are asking now is whether Kalanick can continue to serve as the public face of the company he created. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/01/517988142/uber-ceo-apologizes-over-video-of-dispute-with-driver

item.title: After Video Of Dispute With Driver, Uber CEO Says He Needs To 'Grow Up'
item.description: March 1, 2017 - Travis Kalanick apologized Tuesday for his actions in a video posted this week, in which Kalanick had a heated argument with an Uber driver after the driver raised complaints about pay.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - Travis Kalanick apologized Tuesday for his actions in a video posted this week, in which Kalanick had a heated argument with an Uber driver after the driver raised complaints about pay. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/01/517905730/after-video-of-fight-with-driver-uber-ceo-says-he-needs-to-grow-up

item.title: Amazon Cloud Outage Disrupts Traffic For Websites, Apps
item.description: March 1, 2017 - The cloud-computing service went down around midday on Tuesday, and Amazon said the issue was resolved just after 5 p.m. ET. Thousands of companies were affected by the outage.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 1, 2017 - The cloud-computing service went down around midday on Tuesday, and Amazon said the issue was resolved just after 5 p.m. ET. Thousands of companies were affected by the outage. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/01/517867769/amazon-cloud-outage-disrupts-traffic-for-websites-apps

item.title: Lawsuit Alleges That PayPal Diverted Donations To Different Charities
item.description: February 28, 2017 - The PayPal Giving Fund says it allows donors to give to a charity of their choice. A class action lawsuit claims the company would, with no notification, redirect funds to different organizations.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - The PayPal Giving Fund says it allows donors to give to a charity of their choice. A class action lawsuit claims the company would, with no notification, redirect funds to different organizations. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/28/517790137/lawsuit-alleges-that-paypal-diverted-donations-to-different-charities

item.title: HMD Global Plans To Bring Back Nokia 3310 Cell Phone
item.description: February 28, 2017 - HMD Global will be relaunching the Nokia 3310, the iconic phone that originally came out in 2000 and became one of the best-selling mobile phones ever.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - HMD Global will be relaunching the Nokia 3310, the iconic phone that originally came out in 2000 and became one of the best-selling mobile phones ever. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/28/517779794/hmd-global-plans-to-bring-back-nokia-3310-cell-phone

item.title: Ford Replaces CD Player With Streaming Music In New Vehicle
item.description: February 28, 2017 - For the first time in 25 years, Ford Motor Company is offering a vehicle without a CD player. The company will replace the CD player with streaming audio and video.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - For the first time in 25 years, Ford Motor Company is offering a vehicle without a CD player. The company will replace the CD player with streaming audio and video. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/28/517779766/ford-replaces-cd-player-with-streaming-music-in-new-vehicle

item.title: Trump May Weigh In On H-1B Visas, But Major Reform Depends On Congress
item.description: February 28, 2017 - President Trump has said he wants to crack down on abuses and protect American workers. But it's Congress that holds the power to fundamentally reform the program, and work there is underway.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 28, 2017 - President Trump has said he wants to crack down on abuses and protect American workers. But it's Congress that holds the power to fundamentally reform the program, and work there is underway. http://www.npr.org/sections/alltechconsidered/2017/02/28/517496648/trump-may-weigh-in-on-h-1b-visas-but-major-reform-depends-on-congress

item.title: Can Sex Offenders Be Barred From Social Media? Justices Lean Toward No
item.description: February 27, 2017 - The court heard two cases today: One on whether the government can deport a resident for a statutory rape conviction, and another on whether a state can criminalize social media use for sex offenders.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - The court heard two cases today: One on whether the government can deport a resident for a statutory rape conviction, and another on whether a state can criminalize social media use for sex offenders. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/27/517563127/can-sex-offenders-be-barred-from-social-media-justices-lean-toward-no

item.title: Privacy Paradox: How To Gain More Control Over Your Data
item.description: February 27, 2017 - The WNYC podcast, "Note to Self," conducted an experiment called The Privacy Paradox, which involved thousands of people who tried to strengthen control over their personal information online.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - The WNYC podcast, "Note to Self," conducted an experiment called The Privacy Paradox, which involved thousands of people who tried to strengthen control over their personal information online. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/27/517563179/privacy-paradox-how-to-gain-more-control-over-your-data

item.title: New FCC Chairman Plans To Block Privacy Regulations
item.description: February 27, 2017 - The Federal Communications Commission's new chairman wants to block a rule approved by his predecessor requiring Internet service providers like Comcast and Verizon adhere to new privacy standards.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - The Federal Communications Commission's new chairman wants to block a rule approved by his predecessor requiring Internet service providers like Comcast and Verizon adhere to new privacy standards. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/27/517563172/new-fcc-chairman-plans-to-block-privacy-regulations

item.title: North Carolina Law Makes Facebook A Felony For Former Sex Offenders
item.description: February 27, 2017 - North Carolina has a law banning sex offenders from social media. The state says sex offenders use sites to find future child victims. The court will decide if this is constitutional.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - North Carolina has a law banning sex offenders from social media. The state says sex offenders use sites to find future child victims. The court will decide if this is constitutional. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/26/517086190/north-carolina-law-makes-facebook-a-felony-for-former-sex-offenders

item.title: To Keep Teens Safe Online, They Need To Learn To Manage Risk
item.description: February 27, 2017 - Teens should be included in efforts to mitigate their online risks, researchers say, but apps focus more on parents controlling access by monitoring and blocking sites.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: February 27, 2017 - Teens should be included in efforts to mitigate their online risks, researchers say, but apps focus more on parents controlling access by monitoring and blocking sites. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/27/517491502/to-keep-teens-safe-online-they-need-to-learn-to-manage-risk
